questions.question_text:
What is the function of the following AWS Key Management Service (KMS) key policy attached to a customer master key (CMK)?
//IMG//

discussion.content:
The questions indicated that KMS key policy is attached to a specific CMK.
All A, B does not mention CMK while D mention its for any CMK.
C correctly states that the policy is for the CMK which policy attached to.

https://docs.aws.amazon.com/kms/latest/developerguide/key-policies.html
Ans: C 100%

D

When you use the kms:ViaService condition key, the service makes the request on behalf of a principal in the AWS account.

Selected Answer: D
D is correct. The "behalf" word is the key point here: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/kms/latest/developerguide/conditions-kms.html#conditions-kms-via-service

Selected Answer: C
C - appears to be the right answer and makes the most sense.

Selected Answer: C
https://www.exam4training.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/12/image020-47.jpg
link for the broken img 

answer is C
Ans: C
C makes sense for me as well
C makes sense

choices.C: The CMK is to be used for encrypting and decrypting only when the principal is ExampleUser and the request comes from WorkMail or SES in the specified region.
choices.D: The key policy allows WorkMail or SES to encrypt or decrypt on behalf of the user for any CMK in the account.
choices.B: The ExampleUser principal can transparently encrypt and decrypt email exchanges specifically between ExampleUser and AWS.
choices.A: The Amazon WorkMail and Amazon SES services have delegated KMS encrypt and decrypt permissions to the ExampleUser principal in the 111122223333 account.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Param store - SecureString is FREE

The most cost-effective solution to meet these requirements would be to store the client token as a SecureString parameter in AWS Systems Manager Parameter Store and use the AWS SDK to retrieve the value of the SecureString parameter in the Lambda function.C

Selected Answer: C
C
for cost effectiveness, systems manager parameter store trumps secrets manager

A unique client token is generated in the SaaS platform to grant access to the Lambda function

(0) most cost effective solution to (1) encrypt the access token at rest and (2) pass the token to the Lambda function at runtime

Unless I am mistaken a Lamda authorizer is Lambda side auth before execution of a Lambda function, not auth of Lambda to the SaaS application. If so, this eliminates B.
A Secrets Manager & C Parameter Store seem to both be possible. Parameter Store is free, Secrets Manager is not so between these C is better but both incur some cost by using the AWS SDK.
D seems possible but has a cost per key
https://medium.com/@kush.saraiya/encrypting-environment-variables-in-aws-lambda-function-e09cdde9fef1

Hard to evaluate the costs on this but I think the 'MOST cost-effectively' is a hint to choose Parameter Store so I think C is the best answer. (disclaimer I have never worked with any of this and am just reading documentation)

comments.content: Clarification - I read this "A unique client token is generated in the SaaS platform to grant access to the Lambda function" to mean that the token is used by the Lambda function to access the SaaS application, not the other way around.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
A Lambda authorizer is useful if you want to implement a custom authorization scheme that uses a bearer token authentication strategy such as OAuth or SAML, or that uses request parameters to determine the caller's identity.
https://docs.aws.amazon.com/apigateway/latest/developerguide/apigateway-use-lambda-authorizer.html
Why B isn't a valid option? Is it because request need to come from 3rd party SAAS solution?

Selected Answer: C
C , most cost-effectively

Selected Answer: C
Agree with C, cost-effectively

Selected Answer: C
Agree with C

Selected Answer: C
C -90%
https://aws.amazon.com/systems-manager/pricing/

choices.D: Use AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) to encrypt the client token. Pass the token to the Lambda function at runtime through an environment variable.
choices.A: Store the client token as a secret in AWS Secrets Manager. Use the AWS SDK to retrieve the secretin the Lambda function.
choices.B: Configure a token-based Lambda authorizer in API Gateway.
choices.C: Store the client token as a SecureString parameter in AWS Systems Manager Parameter Store. Use the AWS SDK to retrieve the value of the SecureString parameter in the Lambda function.

questions.question_text:
An Amazon API Gateway API invokes an AWS Lambda function that needs to interact with a software-as-a-service (SaaS) platform. A unique client token is generated in the SaaS platform to grant access to the Lambda function. A security engineer needs to design a solution to encrypt the access token at rest and pass the token to the Lambda function at runtime.

Which solution will meet these requirements MOST cost-effectively?

choices.D: Grant AWS Glue access to Amazon S3 in a resource-based policy that specifies the organization as the principal.
choices.A: Apply a user policy in the other accounts to allow AWS Glue and Athena to access the .csv file.
choices.B: Use S3 Select to restrict access to the .csv file. In AWS Glue Data Catalog, use S3 Select as the source of the AWS Glue database.
choices.C: Define an AWS Glue Data Catalog resource policy in AWS Glue to grant cross-account S3 object access to the .csv file.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C is correct
https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/big-data/query-cross-account-aws-glue-data-catalogs-using-amazon-athena/

Selected Answer: C
C is the right answer for this
C grants cross account access to the S3 bucket.

Selected Answer: C
Cross-Account = multiple departments and accounts
C is the answer

Selected Answer: C
https://docs.aws.amazon.com/athena/latest/ug/data-sources-glue-cross-account.html

questions.question_text:
A company has multiple departments. Each department has its own AWS account. All these accounts belong to the same organization in AWS Organizations.

A large .csv file is stored in an Amazon S3 bucket in the sales department's AWS account. The company wants to allow users from the other accounts to access the .csv file’s content through the combination of AWS Glue and Amazon Athena. However, the company does not want to allow users from the other accounts to access other files in the same folder.

Which solution will meet these requirements?

A company has multiple accounts in the AWS Cloud. Users in the developer account need to have access to specific resources in the production account.

What is the MOST secure way to provide this access?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D, create role on destination account, grant access to the rol, permit developer user assume permisions 
https://docs.aws.amazon.com/IAM/latest/UserGuide/tutorial_cross-account-with-roles.html

Selected Answer: D
D is correct

The IAM role should be created where the resource is located. In this particular case, users from the developer account need access to the production resource. Therefore, the cross account with the IAM role should be assigned to the production account. D

Selected Answer: D
D is correct

comments.content: because it's cheaper for examtopics to get the right answers from us, later updating their answers to match what we agree on ;-)

discussion.content:
Answer D

why all answers are wrong here

Selected Answer: D
Yup D it is

choices.A: Create one IAM user in the production account. Grant the appropriate permissions to the resources that are needed. Share the password only with the users that need access.
choices.D: Create cross-account access with an IAM role in the production account. Grant the appropriate permissions to this role. Allow users in the developer account to assume this role to access the production resources.
choices.C: Create cross-account access with an IAM user account in the production account. Grant the appropriate permissions to this user account. Allow users in the developer account to use this user account to access the production resources.
choices.B: Create cross-account access with an IAM role in the developer account. Grant the appropriate permissions to this role. Allow users in the developer account to assume this role to access the production resources.

choices.C: The VPC’s route table is not configured correctly.
choices.D: There is no peering connection between the application and the database.
choices.E: The DB instance’s security group is not allowing outbound traffic.
choices.A: The application instance’s security group is not allowing outbound traffic.
choices.B: The network ACL of the application instance’s subnet is not allowing traffic between the application and the DB instance.

comments.content:
I must say, VPC's have defaut Route Tables, so I don't see that argument fit.

If you ask me, I doubt between A, B and C, but i go for A and B since it's the first place I go check to troubleshoot. But I have nothing to back that claim with.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AB
AB
C incorrect - route table are attached on subnet not vpc
D incorrect - same vpc you dont need peering
E incorrect - the outbound traffic rules typically don't apply to DB instances.
https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonRDS/latest/UserGuide/Overview.RDSSecurityGroups.html

Selected Answer: AB
Option C & D can be easily ruled out the fact that both are in the same VPC: 

They should be able to communicate with each other without needing specific route table entries.

Since the application and the DB instance are in the same VPC, a peering connection is not necessary.

Option E: 
The DB instance’s security group would need to allow inbound traffic (not outbound) from the application for a connection to be established.

The questions states that the EC2 instance cannot communicate with the RDS database. 
A) check the security group-outbound rule-EC2 instance
B) check the NACL associated with the EC2 instance

A and B . C - route tables are attached to the subnet. 
D and E don't make sense. 
E - SGs are stateful, if a traffic is allowed to flow in, it is allowed to flow out.
agree with A, B
Answer AB

Selected Answer: AB
AB - 70%

questions.question_text:
A security engineer is attempting to troubleshoot a problem. An application that runs on an Amazon EC2 instance in a VPC cannot communicate with an Amazon RDS DB instance in another subnet of the same VPC. The connection request is timing out.

Which issues could be causing this problem? (Choose two.)
